references.title: Cognitive Drift in Long-Term Knowledge Systems
references.abstract: This study explores the phenomenon of cognitive drift in large-scale knowledge systems over extended periods of use. Using simulated learning environments, the authors demonstrate how accumulated minor inaccuracies can influence system-level reasoning outcomes.

references.title: Temporal Patterns in Synthetic Memory Models
references.abstract: The paper investigates temporal pattern formation in synthetic memory architectures. Results indicate that periodic reinforcement significantly stabilizes memory retrieval accuracy.

references.title: Hierarchical Attention Mechanisms in Abstract Reasoning
references.abstract: This article presents a hierarchical attention framework designed to improve abstract reasoning tasks. Experimental results show notable gains in reasoning depth and inference consistency.

references.title: Information Decay in Distributed Archives
references.abstract: The research analyzes information decay in distributed digital archives. Findings suggest redundancy alone is insufficient without periodic validation protocols.

references.title: Synthetic Narratives and Machine Interpretation
references.abstract: This paper examines how machines construct and interpret synthetic narratives. The authors argue that narrative coherence emerges from constraint-based semantic alignment.

references.title: Modeling Uncertainty in Autonomous Decision Systems
references.abstract: The study proposes a probabilistic framework for representing uncertainty in autonomous decision-making systems, improving robustness in dynamic environments.

references.title: Semantic Compression Techniques for Large Knowledge Bases
references.abstract: This paper introduces semantic compression techniques that reduce storage requirements while maintaining inferential accuracy in large knowledge bases.

references.title: Emergent Structures in Algorithmic Learning
references.abstract: The article explores how emergent structures arise in algorithmic learning systems without explicit programming of higher-order rules.

references.title: Evaluating Interpretability Metrics for Neural Models
references.abstract: This study compares multiple interpretability metrics applied to neural models, highlighting trade-offs between transparency and predictive fidelity.

references.title: Concept Stability in Adaptive Learning Agents
references.abstract: The paper analyzes how adaptive agents maintain concept stability while continuously updating internal representations.

references.title: Cross-Domain Transfer in Artificial Reasoners
references.abstract: This research investigates cross-domain transfer capabilities in artificial reasoners, demonstrating improved efficiency through shared latent representations.

references.title: Formal Constraints in Knowledge Representation
references.abstract: The article discusses formal constraint systems for knowledge representation and their impact on inference consistency.

references.title: Adaptive Feedback Loops in Intelligent Systems
references.abstract: This paper examines adaptive feedback loops and their role in stabilizing intelligent system behavior under uncertainty.

references.title: Quantifying Abstraction in Computational Models
references.abstract: The study proposes metrics for quantifying abstraction levels in computational models and validates them across benchmark tasks.

references.title: Logic-Based Control in Autonomous Frameworks
references.abstract: This article explores logic-based control mechanisms and their application in autonomous system frameworks.

references.title: Scalability Challenges in Knowledge Graph Construction
references.abstract: The paper reviews scalability challenges encountered during large-scale knowledge graph construction and proposes mitigation strategies.

references.title: Contextual Alignment in Multi-Agent Communication
references.abstract: This study analyzes contextual alignment strategies that improve communication efficiency in multi-agent environments.

references.title: Robust Learning in Noisy Environments
references.abstract: This paper presents techniques for maintaining learning accuracy in the presence of noisy training data, with applications to real-world sensor data processing.

references.title: Chrysalis: A Unified System for Comparing Active Teaching and Passive Learning with AI Agents in Education
references.abstract: AI-assisted learning has seen a remarkable uptick over the last few years, mainly due to the rise in popularity of Large Language Models (LLMs). Their ability to hold long-form, natural language interactions with users makes them excellent resources for exploring school- and university-level topics in a dynamic, active manner. We compare students'experiences when interacting with an LLM companion in two capacities: tutored learning and learning-by-teaching. We do this using Chrysalis, an LLM-based system that we have designed to support both AI tutors and AI teachable agents for any topic. Through a within-subject exploratory study with 36 participants, we present insights into student preferences between the two strategies and how constructs such as intellectual humility vary between these two interaction modes. To our knowledge, we are the first to conduct a direct comparison study on the effects of using an LLM as a tutor versus as a teachable agent on multiple topics. We hope that our work opens up new avenues for future research in this area.

references.title: The clonal and mutational evolution spectrum of primary triple-negative breast cancers
references.abstract: No abstract available.

references.title: Radiopharmaceuticals for PET and SPECT Imaging: A Literature Review over the Last Decade
references.abstract: Positron emission tomography (PET) uses radioactive tracers and enables the functional imaging of several metabolic processes, blood flow measurements, regional chemical composition, and/or chemical absorption. Depending on the targeted processes within the living organism, different tracers are used for various medical conditions, such as cancer, particular brain pathologies, cardiac events, and bone lesions, where the most commonly used tracers are radiolabeled with 18F (e.g., [18F]-FDG and NA [18F]). Oxygen-15 isotope is mostly involved in blood flow measurements, whereas a wide array of 11C-based compounds have also been developed for neuronal disorders according to the affected neuroreceptors, prostate cancer, and lung carcinomas. In contrast, the single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) technique uses gamma-emitting radioisotopes and can be used to diagnose strokes, seizures, bone illnesses, and infections by gauging the blood flow and radio distribution within tissues and organs. The radioisotopes typically used in SPECT imaging are iodine-123, technetium-99m, xenon-133, thallium-201, and indium-111. This systematic review article aims to clarify and disseminate the available scientific literature focused on PET/SPECT radiotracers and to provide an overview of the conducted research within the past decade, with an additional focus on the novel radiopharmaceuticals developed for medical imaging.
